text: Now comes the moon riding over the horizon. Upon a hill a the edge of the wood squats a castle, its crude stonework bathed in cold silvery light. Queer carvings and runes  decorate the ponderous gate. Heavy vines are climbing up walls. The castle is old, its unfamiliar form testament t an ancient mind and an ancient craft. Flickering candle l dances on a leaded windowpane. Inside, the corridors are dark and silent. Under low arch ceilings the uneven floors are paved with stone blocks.  Perched over lintels and crouched in niches are icons wit strange animal heads.
A sleep on a straw palette in a room strewn with vegetabl and crockery is Hodge, a wrinkled old retainer. A flicker candle and empty jug are beside the bed. He is snoring ge

This circular chamber at the heart of the castle is stuff with parchments, scrolls, dusty books, bronze braziers, g retorts, chemical salts, birds both stuffed and caged. An iron candelabra stands on a work table, tapers burning. I the soft glow it seems that the room is unoccupied, but n moving in the background is a shadowy figure, preparing f a magical deed. Feet are positioned carefully within a  pentagram chiseled into the floor. A scroll is consulted; comes an arm and a voice blurts out:
Omnia in duos: Duo in Unum: Unus in  Nihil: Haec nec Quattuor nec Omnia  nec Duo nec Unus nec Nihil Sunt.
Nothing happens.
Come on, candles, out!
But the little flames stand at attention without so much a tremble.
In Volunta Divina et Verbum Magi:  Lux! Exstinguat!
It's no use. There is a sigh and the figure moves forward into the light. Revealed in the glow is the discouraged f of Galen Bradwardyn, sorcerer's apprentice.
Carrying the candelabra, the youth trudges up a circular  staircase.

The highest point of the castle is a turret, open to the  stars and the night air. Here, more magic is afoot. An ol enchanter, Ulrich, Magister Ipsissimus, pours water from silver ewer into a stone bowl. As the surface ripples  disappear he leans forward and gazes into the pool. All a once his face hardens as the distant sounds of screams an thunder reach his ears. Lights and shadows, reflected fro within the basin, play across his face. His frown deepens the sound of his own voice comes to him from the vision i the water -- Draco draconis -- suddenly squelched by the  roar of flame and an ugly snarl. At that moment Galen reaches the top of the steps and hol up the candelabra.
Vide, Magister. There's something  wrong.
Ulrich, startled from his trance, slaps the water out of basin and turns to confront his student. Galen is taken a by the old man's grim countenance.
What's the matter? What's happened?
I've just seen something. Something  of consequence to you.
To me?
(calm) Yes. My own death.
With a distracted gesture he causes the flames to extingu themselves.
Perhaps we had better hasten your  training.
Outside the castle wall Hodge is feeding the chickens and ducks. He straightens up and squints through the early mo mists. On a distant hillock two figures are moving toward the woods.
Hobbling slowly with the aid of a pair of canes, Ulrich g his pupil across a wooden bridge and along a stream into forest.

(stern and troubled) This wood, these leaves, the birds,  the very dome of heaven, once they  all rang with one great chord: and  philosophers like me kept it all in  tune. Now, new voices are singing  new songs. (sharply) Have you mastered the threefold  transmutation?
Of course.
(skeptical) You have?
Well, almost.
It's very difficult. Have you  committed to memory undying the Codex  de Profundis?
(a shrug) The first two chapters.
It's long. And what about the Ritual  of Banishment as prescribed by my  late master Balisarius?
To tell the truth, I haven't dared  try it. What's the point, anyway?
The point? The point is you don't  know it, and you're no magician  without it. It was my hope to school  you, to mold your faculties and  wits... I still believe you have  some talent. Somewhere.
I hate books. I hate drill. I want a  real task.
There's no time now. When I'm gone,  half the powers in the universe will  vanish with me. And what's the use  of a few lingering skills if they're  left in the hands of a child? (pause) Listen!
I don't hear anything.
Ulrich gauges the young man standing before him and makes decision. Reaching under his cloak he lifts off a fine si chain with an amulet dangling from it. He drapes it aroun Galen's neck.
Here, wear this.
Galen instinctively wraps his hand around the jewel. He c an ear.
Voices, singing on the road.

He hastens forward to a promontory, eager to have a look. Ulrich does not follow. Instead, doffing his cloak, he wh it before him, where it magically floats a few feet off t ground. Awkwardly, the old man clambers aboard.
I don't see anything.
He turns back, but the wizard is gone. A shadow falls ove him. He looks up. There, two hundred feet above the tree  tops his master is soaring on the wind.
The old conjurer squints into the distance. Miles away an far below a company of drab walkers winds along the margi of the forest. They are singing a mournful round.
He gawks skyward. Suddenly, the old man leans down and  addresses him.
(a shout) We have visitors!

Clustering together in the center of a wide reception hal is a contingent of weary peasants, awkward amidst the dus rugs, drapes and heavy furniture. Their leader is a fineb youth, not yet twenty. Like the others, he is uneasy; his name is Valerian. Hodge enters and sets a tray of mead be them. He leaves without a word. The visitors stare glumly the refreshment, but are too timorous to go near it.
Galen helps Ulrich prepare for the audience. The sorcerer peers at himself in a full-length mirror, adjusting the h of a black robe.
Looks forbidding enough, don't you  think?
Here are your sticks.

No -- they'll think me infirm. You  know, Balisarius wore this whenever  he changed lead into gold. He could  really do that, you know. I never  could. Too bad -- you'd stand to  inherit some real wealth.
You're in a morbid frame of mind.  What's all this about dying? You  don't even look sick.
(tying on a sash) You still wearing that amulet? (Galen nods) Good. Don't lose it. It still belongs  to me.
He backs away from the mirror and fits a silver coronet o his head.
Now, adeptus minor, get yourself a  handful of that sulphurous ash over  there...
The sorcerer starts down a circular stone staircase.

The visitors watch warily as a door swings open and Galen makes his entrance, his face expressionless and hands pre together. He looks rather young to be the famous Ulrich. Galen allows a moment to go by, then throws his arms wide Ka-whump! and Ulrich appears in the doorway in a smoky  fireball. Alarmed, the visitors retreat.
Nunc habeus lux!
Pffst! around the room candles flare in their niches.
Et calor!
In the fireplace, the birch logs are suddenly ablaze. Ulr totters to the hearth and extends long bony fingers towar the warmth.
Welcome to Cragganmore. I am Ulrich.  Which one of you calls himself  Valerian?
The travelers are suitably dazzled by the magician's  performance. The young leader of the party screws up his  courage and speaks.
That would be me. We are here on  behalf...
I know why you're here. You're a  delegation from Urland, from beyond  Dalvatia. Let's see the artifacts.

The travelers exchange nervous glances. Valerian motions one of his companions. The man steps forward and hands ov a leather pouch. One by one, Valerian places the contents the table for Ulrich's inspection.
A bone. Scorched. A rock, fire- blackened. (pause) Scales.
At this, Ulrich advances and closely examines three shimm irridescent disks as big as saucers.
All right. How did you come by these?
(proudly) I found them. At the mouth of the  lair.
(grim) What else?
Valerian reaches under his jerkin and withdraws what appe to be a curved sword. He jabs it into the table.
A claw.
That's no claw. It's a tooth. By the  gods!
He runs a finger along a serrated edge and gazes bleakly his visitors.
And you want me to do battle with  that?
Valerian has lost all trace of timidity.

Who else can we turn to? We all know  what we're dealing with here. This  is a basilicok. (he takes a step  forward) A cockatrice. (another step, bolder) A dragon. (he leans close to  Ulrich) This is no stag, no bear, no natural  creature. This is one of your kind.  And only a necromancer such as  yourself can rid us of it.
Did you try the Meredydd sisters?  What about Rinbod? I've heard it  said he killed a dragon once.
They're all dead. You're the only  one left.
With a sigh, Ulrich lowers himself into a chair. He rubs withered legs and shakes his head.
It's a long way to Urland.
Every quarter, upon the solstices  and the equinoxes there's a new  victim.
Greil, a grizzled peasant, speaks up.
My daughter, for one.
My sister... cousins...
All women?
Girls. Virgins, to be exact, chosen  by lot.
Galen edges over to the table and inspects the scales and tooth.
Master, don't you think --
Silence!
He broods for a long time.
Are you afraid of dragons?
No. Sorcerers and dragons go back a  long long time together. If it weren't  for sorcerers, there wouldn't be any  dragons. (pause) All right. I'll go.
The travelers are making ready for departure in the grey  light of dawn. As Hodge stuffs provisions into a wicker b Ulrich wraps padding on a newly fashioned pair of crutche

I know of this dragon. Vermithrax  Pejorative: she's four hundred years  old. As far as I can tell she's the  last of her kind. Very appropriate  that I'm the one to finish her off,  don't you think? (he tries out the  crutches) There. Flatten the highest mountain.  What say you, Galen? (no answer) Speak up. (still no answer) You, Hodge.
Hodge mutters something inaudible and grimly keeps packin
(to Galen) While I'm gone see you keep your  nose in your books and your hands  out of my reagents. Leave my  instruments alone too.
Galen crouches against the castle wall; he regards his ma sullenly.
Look at yourself. How far will you  get like that? A league, two leagues?
I'm not worried about the road.
(sarcastic) Why don't you wave your hands around  and summon up a coach-and-four?
Don't mock me.
Galen gets up and calls out to the Urlanders.
You pilgrims: You're used to  lotteries. Why not draw straws to  see who'll be first to carry  ironshanks here.
This is too much for Hodge.
Hold your tongue. If the master's  got a mind to go, he'll go.
Galen approaches the old sorcerer.
Send me. You're always saying I need  seasoning. I need a test. Let me go.
You're not ready.
I'm ready for anything.
(wan smile) Don't be so hasty. Your time will  come.
The walkers are ready to set forth. Hodge picks up his pa steps forward and pulls open the great gate.
Three mounted men are outside the gate, helmets on their  heads, swords on the belts and longbows across their  shoulders. They look formidable. The Urlanders take a ste backward.
Tyrian!?
Tyrian is a lean, heavily bearded nobleman. There is a co of arms on the shield strapped to the pommel of his saddl
(amiable) Good morning, all.
We're not afraid of you. Give us the  road.
Why, the road is yours. All the way  to Urland. It's a long journey, isn't  it? But when you're in search of a  sorcerer, I suppose no distance is  too great.
Sensing trouble, Galen moves forward. Ulrich touches his  arm.
(under his breath) Say nothing.
Galen hears the urgency in the old man's voice and obeys. Hodge takes it upon himself to deal with the strangers.
What do you want with us?
Well, like my good friends here,  I've come for a bit of black magic.  No doubt you've heard of our troubles  at home. This is Cragganmore, is it  not?
Aye, this be the place of Ulrich.
Tyrian dismounts and saunters up to the old magician.
And here we have the mystical presence  himself, no?
You'd best keep your distance -- and  your manners.

If he's ready to lay a dragon in its  grave, he's got nothing to fear from  me. (turns to the Urlanders) I've no more love for that creature  than you lot. Nor has the King. But,  before you stir things up, don't you  think it a good idea to see you've  got the right man for the job?
Aha -- it's a test you're looking  for. We don't do tests.

I'm sure you don't. They never do  tests -- and not many real deeds  either. Oh, conversation with your  grandmother's shade in a darkened  room, the odd love potion or two...  but comes a doubter, well then, it's  the wrong day, the planets are not  aligned, the entrails aren't  favorable, we don't do tests.
We've got no doubts. We require no  test.
And you're not going to get one.
When Ulrich finally speaks, his voice is low and  authoritative.
(to Galen) Go to the conjuring room. The iron  box. Fetch me the dagger within.
Galen's eyes widen with alarm.
The dagger. Be quick.
Galen dashes into the castle. Ulrich gazes almost shyly a Tyrian.
You shall have your test.

Galen comes puffing up the steps, locates the iron box, a flings it open. Amidst the tawdry paraphernalia of a  professional magician is an ivory-handled dagger covered  with runic inscriptions. Galen eagerly examines it to see how the blade might twist aside or collapse into the hand but it is all too genuine. A murder weapon.
(impatient) Where are you, boy? I'm waiting.
Galen throws open a window and looks down into the courty He displays the dagger.
Not this one, was it?
The very one. Let it fall.

Galen hesitates, then tosses it. Tumbling end over end, i arcs downward. The old conjurer calmly stretches out a ha and plucks it neatly out of the air. Galen watches as Ulr passes the weapon to Tyrian and strips back his robe expo a bony chest. Galen knows what's coming. He rushes for th door. He's only a step away when it bangs shut of its own accord. He sprints for a second exit. Whack! This door sl shut too. Locked in. Quick, back to the window and climb  down the vine... Smack! the heavy shutters seal him in.
Ulrich takes Tyrian's arm and guides the point of the dag to his breastbone.
Vita regula, vita hieratica!

Everyone is filled with dread. Hodge is shaking. From the castle come the rattling of shutters and Galen's muffled  cries. A sick sarcastic smile has crept over Tyrian's lip He tenses himself to thrust.
Go on. Don't worry, you can't hurt  me.

Galen stops hammering and presses his face to a crack in shutter. Below he can see the participants in this grisly drama. He holds his breath. Tyrian makes a sudden movemen and buries the blade in Ulrich's chest. But the sorcerer  stands unbent, seemingly unhurt. Then, after a long momen he slowly sags forward over the dagger and the hand that  holds it. Tyrian shrinks back and allows the body to fall a heap. Very quickly he remounts. In another moment he an his companions are gone. The others are riveted in horror Hodge sinks to his knees and wails his grief. Galen turns away from the window and gazes blankly into t gloomy conjuring room. Click! The doors unlatch themselve and swing open.

Ulrich, principal magician and sorcerer of the western wo reposes on a hardwood pyre. His hands are folded on his c His face is peaceful. While the visitors wordlessly look Galen touches a burning brand to the kindling. At first t fire catches normally enough, but when the flames start t envelop the body they suddenly turn pale green, producing unearthly roar. The onlookers back away from the intense  heat.
The erstwhile apprentice stands his ground, blinking back tears, his face weirdly illuminated by the fire.

Galen sits alone amidst the museum-like collection of mag apparatus. He stares at the amulet, considering its  significance. His reverie is interrupted by the murmur of voices below. At the window he looks down to see Hodge bi farewell to the delegation from Urland. Valerian is the l to leave. He pauses at the gate and glances up at Galen.  Then he moves on. The young student of magic sets his jaw suddenly filled with resolve. Moving through the room, he busies himself with the old m effects. He scoops up the loose books and parchments and  locks them into trunks. He drapes muslin cloths over the  alchemical devices. He sows a handful of salt over the  pentagram inscribed in the floor. Finally, he opens the c and releases the crow, the falcon, and the great horned o

Hodge is up on the burned out funeral pyre, anxiously scr ashes and small bones into a leather pouch -- the remains Ulrich. Up behind him comes Galen, now clad in a traveler cloak, with a pack on his back and a staff in his hand.
Hodge -- what are you doing?
Hodge quickly conceals the pouch.
Just making my farewell, thank you  very much.
He quickly climbs down, picks up his pack and follows Gal out through the gate. As the door is pushed shut a huge o timber falls into place, barring the castle against the  uninvited.

Galen and Hodge labor to the crest of a grassy hill and t to look back across a wide valley. There on another hillt on the far side sits Cragganmore, lit by the red rays of setting sun. Galen removes the amulet from his neck and  clutches it in his fist. Hodge is bug-eyed to see it.
Be careful with that! You don't know  what you're doing.
Stand back!
He raises his hands toward the castle and calls out:
Cragganmore! Domus non i am! Silva  celet!

The vines on the castle walls begin to twitch and stretch magically brought to animate life. They flow upward over masonry, branching out and covering every surface, then u onto the roof. Finally only the tops of the chimneys and highest turrets stand above the green carpet. A century's growth in a matter of seconds.
On their hilltop the old retainer gives the youth a fearf look. Galen is too flushed with excitement over what he h done to notice.
Galen and Hodge trudge along an overgrown cart-track unde an arch of trees.
Oh, it's a vale of tears in which we  dwell. It doesn't matter who you  are, a king in his robes, a peasant  in his rags, when your time comes,  no magic can save you...
I guess...
The apprentice's mind is elsewhere: he's got a coin hover in mid-air above his palm, bobbing gently as he walks.

...the kindest lord a man could ask  for... now he's gone. Ye gods he was  fussy about his bath. And you'd think  he could boil his own eggs with the  snap of a finger, but no, he had old  Hodge do it, of course. (snurfling) Up before five I was, mucking out  the cages, slopping the pigs, and  never once got so much as a thankyou  or a pat on the back... (through tears) I'm going to miss him.
Me too...
He plucks a low-hanging leaf, waves a hand over it, and  watches it turn into a spray of daffodils.
No you don't. All you care about is  the tricks and knavery. Well, you  don't pull any wool over these old  eyes. It'll be a mighty long walk  before you fill his shoes, you mark  my word.
What's the matter, Hodge, pack too  heavy? Here.
He gives the pack a slap. It flies out of its harness and floats alongside them. Hodge snatches it back and clutche it tightly.
Careful with that!
Too cold, is it?
A great coat drapes itself over Hodge's shoulders.
Stop it!
Too warm?
The greatcoat disappears, as do the rest of his garments, leaving him in his smalls.
(spluttering) Stop it, I say! Out of respect for  the master!
Suppressing a grin, Galen mercifully waves his hand and  restores Hodge to his usual costume.
I've got as much respect for the  master as anyone, old man. But --  then again, I'm master now.
The Urlanders are gathered around a fire, sharing a meage supper. The man named Greil pokes at the stew-pot.
I left my farm with seeds unplanted,  calves unborn, nothing but a wife to  chase down the strays, and for what?  A funeral, that's what.
He walks up and down behind Valerian.
Because some people said, find a  magician. Not just a local fellow,  an import, a good forty leagues from  home. An all-powerful necromancer.  Ha -- some necromancer!
Malkin, an older man, speaks up.
Hold your tongue, Greil. Sit. Eat.
I'll not sit. I'll not eat. See you  the Great Bear. His tail points east.  It's the equinox. Have you forgotten?  Or rather not think about it?
(miserable) He's right. I brought us here for  nothing. May the gods help whoever's  daughter it is tonight.

There is a noise from the darkness beyond the campfire. T of the men get to their feet and listen. At first silence then more rustling. Without a word the two men dart into bushes and haul two interlopers before the company: Galen and Hodge.
Good morrow, good morrow. Peace be  with you.
Easy now. We mean no harm. We've  been looking for you.
(growl) Well, you've found us.
(brushing himself off) More the other way around, I'd say.
What do you want?
A few words, that's all. You were  looking for a conjurer.
He's dead.
Right. Requiscat in pace. (he takes a deep breath) Ecce: magister novus!
How say you?
Galen surveys the puzzled faces. He draws himself up and  plunges in:

My lord Ulrich is no longer. All  that you asked of him, you may now  expect of me. The dangers he would  face, I will now conquer. The task  he would undertake I will now fulfill.  I am Galen Bradwardyn, inheritor of  Ulrich's craft and knowledge, and I  am the Sorcerer you seek.
There is a moment of depressed silence. Hodge rolls his e Greil starts to chuckle, then to laugh. Soon the others a laughing too.
Well, that's a handsome thought, O  wizard of wizards. But if there's  one thing our friend Tyrian has shown  us, it's to beware the pig in the  poke. Who's got a dagger?
No tests!!
Call it proof, then.
Someone brings out a dagger and hands it to Greil. Valeri pushes it away.
We've seen enough tests.
But Greil persists, waving the knife at the group.
Well I haven't. All I've seen is  death. Death in our families, death  on the road, and tonight, death at  home.
He lashes out with the knife. Galen jumps back, but Valer steps in, delivering a quick kick to Greil's gut, followe by a right to the jaw that sends the bigger man sprawling He takes the knife.
What's come over you, anyway? Have  you lost your wits?
He propels Galen out of harm's way and sits him down on t other side of the fire. Greil nurses his jaw.

I don't like it. Young snot-nose  comes in here for sport at our  expense. We're on a fool's errand,  but we don't have to listen to this.  I don't want to hear any more about  sorcery. I don't want to hear any  more about spells.
Valerian hands Galen a plate of food.
You must be hungry.
(nods) What's the matter with him?
It's not just him. It's all of us.  It's the equinox.
They both look up at the moon.

The moon shines down on the far reaches of the Kingdom of Urland, coldly lighting a barren landscape filled with th skeletons of dead trees, blackened rock and bare ground.  Advancing across this mournful terrain is a troop of arme men leading a blindfolded horse and tumbril. The horse is skittish. Finally, in spite of shouts and lashings, it re to go further. The leader, Horsrik, barks out an order:
Close enough! Bring her out!

A young woman, no more than seventeen, is brought forth f the cart. Long black hair falls down over a white tunic. dark eyes dart fearfully around in her pale face. She is  half-carried, half dragged to the edge of a steaming crac in the ground where she is manacled to a wooden post. By  lantern-light, Horsrik reads from a parchment scroll.
Now be it known throughout the  kingdom, that this maiden, having  lawfully been chosen by a deed of  fortune and destiny, shall hereby  give up her life for the greater  good of Urland.
There is a low rumble; the earth shakes. Horsrik glances  nervously around. He carries on by rote.
By this act shall be satisfied the  powers that dwell underground and  the spirits that attend thereto. In  gratitude for this sacrifice His  Majesty has declared the family --  what's the name? --
He prods the girl, but she is too terrified to speak. Ben them, the earth seems to groan. Smoke issues from the mou of the pit. One of the nervous witnesses leans forward.
Plowman! The family Plowman!
(rushing it) -- the family Plowman to be free of  obligations, taxations, levys and  imposts for a period not to exceed  five years...
The horse suddenly rears, and blindfold notwithstanding,  gallops off, dragging the tumbril over the rocks. The men behind Horsrik break ranks and scatter.
-- ordained and signed this day,  etc., Casiodorus, in his glory the  reigning king of this our realm...  his seal, his mark, duly read by  Chancellor Horsrik in his holy name.
Now Horsrik joins the flight, chasing his men back over t murky horizon.

She strains against her manacles, cocking her head to lis as the rumblings below subside. Presently the steam and s blow away and she can see the horse pawing and stamping a hundred yards distant, the wheel of the cart jammed betwe rocks. Summoning up a wild will to live, she squeezes her hands against the cold iron rings. No use. She spits on h wrists and twists desperately. Blood starts. One hand sli free. She looks at the horse. The animal tosses off its  blindfold and looks back at her. Now she strains again an pulls her other hand free. She wipes the blood on her fro and sprints toward the horse. But she doesn't get there. earth abruptly shifts from under her feet, tumbling her a cracked and steaming rocks. When she raises her head a hu shadow has fallen over the horse. There is a piteous whin then a roar. The girl's face is suddenly lit by flames. S scrambles to her feet and rushes back the other way.

The girl hasn't taken a dozen steps when something huge  hurtles forward and blocks her way. Something scaly and  glittering. She whirls and stumbles off in a new directio This time she's cut off by a monstrous claw tipped with r like talons. She screams and crawls away. Another claw  prevents her escape.
Membranous wings fold down against the night sky. Up come the silhouette of a reptilian head swaying on a serpentin neck. There's an angry hiss. A sheet of flame envelops  everything.
Tyrian kneels beside a mountain waterfall, having a drink while his men hover in the background. One of them points down the slope.
There. I see them.
Tyrian wipes his mouth unhurriedly and strolls over to lo Far below, half hidden by trees, the little company of  Urlanders winds its way through the forest. A frown creeps over Tyrian's face.
Who's that old man?
Where? Which one?
That one. That's the man from  Cragganmore. Now what's he doing  here?
Filling in for the chief, I reckon.
(weary) What a pity.

Hodge marches along with the rest. When he's sure no one  else is looking he burrows into his garments and brings o the leather pouch containing Ulrich's ashes. Reassured th it's still with him, he tucks it away again. Galen falls  into step.
What have you got there?
None of your business.
A little gold, eh? What do you say I  change it into lead?
Save your jokes for someone else.  Me, I don't care for braggarts.
They pass Valerian, who has dropped out of line.
And I don't care for frauds.
I'm no fraud.
Call it fool then. Upstart. Whatever  pleases you.
Hodge, nobody forced you to come  along.
Oh, I'm here of my own free will,  all right. We each do the master's  bidding in our own way.
Well, if he told you I needed  wetnursing, why don't you just turn  yourself around and go back home.
Hodge snorts and fusses with his pack.
Home, is it? You've seen to that,  haven't you? Gone to seed, I'd say...
He glances over and discovers Galen missing.
He walks back along the trail, looking for Valerian. Pret soon the rest of the travelers are out of sight. He hears the sound of a splash. He turns off the trail and pushes  through some shrubbery.
Under the oaks and hickory, a forest stream has widened i a quiet pool. A pile of clothes lies on a rock at the edg Out in the middle, Valerian is treading water.
You're too far behind us. Come on  out.
You go ahead, I'll catch up.
Not a good idea to get separated.  Let's go.
Right. I'll be along.
Galen leans over and splashes some water on his face. Fee good. He shucks his pack and starts to throw off his clot Valerian doesn't like it.
That's all right. Don't come in.
But Galen is now naked and walking into the water. He swi out toward Valerian.
(edgy) You better get back to the group,  they're probably worried.
Galen keeps swimming.
I prefer to swim alone, if you don't  mind.
But Galen has slipped beneath the surface; he doesn't hea
Galen works his way through the murky green underwater wo Suddenly, he stops short and stares. He's only a few feet from Valerian's dangling legs. He gasps in surprise. Vale is no boy.
Galen comes shooting to the surface, coughing and sputter
By the gods!
Valerian is pale and frightened.
Stay away.
She propels herself backward, then turns and swims for sh
Galen and Valerian have taken refuge behind separate bush Briskly they pull on their clothes.
I suppose you'll tell everyone. Go  ahead, I don't care. It's a relief.
I'm not going to say anything.
I don't blame you. I was stupid.  Careless. A silly woman!
(feeble bluff) Take it easy. I knew the moment I  saw you. I've known the whole time.
You never knew a thing. No one knew.  Not since I was born. Go on, run off  and tell them. It'll make a great  story.
Don't worry. No one's going to find  out. Just tell me: why?
Ask my father.
They finish dressing in silence. Finally:
The lottery! Daughters are chosen,  but sons are not!
That's right. Unless you have plenty  of gold or property.
What do you mean?
If you're rich enough, your name  never goes in. (bitter) My father is poor. So are a lot of  fathers.
He studies her. She jams a hat down over her head and, on more the young man, stalks off.

Galen walks down to the edge of the pool to retrieve his  pack. As he leans over he catches sight of what appears t be a reflection in the water: Tyrian on horseback. He whi around, but no one is behind him. Riveted by the vision, hurries along the bank to follow it. After a few paces th blurry figure dismounts, unslings a longbow, nocks an arr and draws the string taut.
(horrified) No!
Galen sprints through the trees. Up ahead is Valerian, wa resolutely.
No!
She glances back at him and grimly keeps on walking. Gale shoots past her and on into the forest.
Hodge!

Galen races up the trail rounds a bend and sees the Urlan coming toward him. Hodge precedes the group with an unste gait. He sees Galen, raises up his arms and flops face do on the trail. A long arrow protrudes from his back. Galen kneels beside him. The uneasy company keeps its distance. Hodge struggles to speak.
Galen? Can you hear me?
I hear you.
You know, somebody shot me, but I  can still talk. There's something  that has to be done.
I know.
Not that cockatrice. Ulrich's ashes.  Here.
Hodge's hand comes out from under his coat gripping the  leather pouch. Galen tugs at it, but Hodge can't let go.
Take it. Sorry, you'll have to peel  it loose.
Galen pries the sack out of Hodge's clenched fingers. Sud the hand comes up, grabs Galen by the hair, and pulls him near.
(a croak) ...burning water... find the lake,  throw it in...
(holding up the pouch) What are you doing with this, Hodge?
...burning water...
He dies. Galen frees himself from his grasp.
Hodge, don't die. Listen to me. You're  not going to die.
Galen is frantic. He pulls out the amulet and wraps his h around it.
Excede, mortem! Revoca, vitam! (he shakes the body) Excede, mortem! Revoca, vitam!

But Hodge has passed on, and Galen's magic has no way to  reach him. Suddenly the youth cries out in pain. He drops the amulet and looks at his palm. The device has burned h flesh. Now he becomes aware of troubled Urlanders looking over his shoulder, witness to his failure.

Wind whips the leaden wave tops on a vast rainy lake. The travelers are rowing across in an open longboat, aided by tattered lateen sail. Valerian mans the steering oar at t stern while Galen broods in the bow. He feels like an imp in their eyes.
The boat pulls into a long narrow waterway with granite c on either side. Moving through swirls of fog, they beach boat and step out onto a craggy shore. Greil leans over a kisses a rock.
Urland!

The travelers descend a mountain pass and emerge through wrack of cloud into a gray and cheerless region. Fire- blackened trees dot the barren landscape. As they reach t flatlands, the Urlanders instinctively pick up the pace.  Galen slows to inspect the weird surroundings. Valerian t past him.
Come on. Don't dawdle here.
Galen falls into step with her.
The whole kingdom like this?
No. We're near the lair. Keep moving.
Galen looks around with new interest.
Where?
Over there. Doesn't matter. We're in  no danger if we just pass through  quickly.
Galen stops. High on the slope beside them is a gaping  fissure.
I see it. Let's have a look.
No!
But Galen is already toiling up the incline.
Greil! Malkin! Help!
The travelers turn to see what's the matter.
Galen approaches the lair, pausing beside a wooden post w iron manacles dangling from it. He fingers them thoughtfu Malkin, Greil and Valerian rush up behind him, their face drawn with worry.
Look, you don't have to do this. We  know you're a fine young magician.  None better. There's no need to prove  it to us.
Are there other entrances?
No. One's enough.
Come on. The road's this way. We'll  tell everybody how close you got.
(coolly) No smoke. How do you know it's in  there?
Don't be a fool. Come away now and  live to tell about it.

Instead, Galen starts into the crack. Greil and Malkin ha away, but Valerian lingers, watching in mounting frustrat as Galen probes further and further into the lair. She pi up a fistful of stones and throws them at him.
Go ahead! You're going to die! What  a fine trick that will be!
But Galen is lost in the gloom. She flees.

Galen puts his hand on the rugged wall: the rocks are hot the touch. Something glinting on the floor catches Galen' eye: an irridescent disk, a dragon scale. It flashes the  colors of the rainbow as Galen examines it. All at once t ground shudders; chunks of rock fall from the ceiling. A  pall of smoke billows up from the depths.

Galen staggers out of the fissure coughing and gagging in swirl of smoke. There is no sign of the Urlanders. He thr down his pack, climbs onto a huge boulder and surveys the massive cliffs rising behind the lair. He grasps the amul and closes his eyes.
Now, great mountain, hear my command:  Terrae lapsus consignet latibulum  draconis! Evanescat latibulum  draconis!

With a thunderous splitting sound, the entire top of the  cliff pitches forward and topples onto the lower half of mountain, sweeping tons of debris into the air. Boulders size of houses bound down the mountain toward the magicia Eyes wide with awe, he turns and runs for his life. Even he careens down the slope, chunks of rock rumble past. On catches him at the knee and sends him flying. He covers his head and joins the landslide. Finally the d lifts and he finds himself in a gully face to face with t cowering Urlanders. They look with real fear at the man w just conjured up the Apocalypse. Tattered and torn, cover with dirt, Galen climbs up out of the shelter for a look his handiwork.

The territory has been drastically transformed: the drago lair is now buried beneath hundreds of tons of broken gra The Urlanders look upon the new landscape with stupefacti Galen grins a triumphant split-lip grin that fails to win them over. Presently they back away and run off down the  trail, Valerian in their midst. Galen's grin fades.

The Village of Swanscombe is little more than a rough and ready collection of thatched huts and mud-daubed outbuild surrounded by cultivated fields. Dogs sleep in open door- ways; chickens peck around the communal well -- but there are no people in evidence as Valerian and her company tro into town.
She trots across the square and enters a deserted blacksm shop.
Father? Hello?
She goes over to the forge. Hot coals are burning. She be aware of a sound -- voices -- chanting.

She walks across the square toward the voices. She is joi by Greil, Malkin and the other travelers, all of them puz by the desolation. As they approach the grange hall the v grow louder. They seem to be singing. The main doors open briefly and three villagers scamper out, dripping wet and wrapped in white muslin. Valerian and her companions look each other in astonishment.

In a wooden cistern in the middle of the hall a woman is  being held under water. After a few moments she is pulled the surface by a tall red-haired man with long bony finge Brother Jacopus Januensis, a Carthusian monk. There's a w cross on his chest and a mad look in his eye. Gathered ar him are the missing villagers, every man woman and child, here to be baptised and sing a few newly-learned hymns in praise of Our Lord Jesus Christ.
Now are you cleansed of your sins!  Now are you born again, purified in  spirit, into the fellowship of Jesus  Christ!
The travelers enter and mingle with the congregation. Val scans the crowd until she locates her father, Simon, a ba sturdy journeyman. He's overjoyed at her return and gives her a hearty embrace.
Welcome back, my son.
Father, what are you doing? Have you  all lost your minds?
Some have.
He points to the monk, who is dunking a screaming infant carrying on about the Bishop of Rome.
It's this monk. He can read and write,  and talk too, I'm afraid.
And they listen?
Shh! They think this a holy place, a  tabernacle.
This is the granary. What kind of  welcome is this? I've got news of  the sorcerer and news of the dragon.
You were brave to go, you and your  friends. But nobody cares. Listen --  he knows what they want to hear.
Brother Jacopus strides back and forth before the assembl in an inspired state.

The man who walks with Christ is not  a man to fear a dragon: Yea, though  I walk through the valley of the  shadow of death I will fear no evil!  You say you are preyed upon by a  foul beast. Yes, but what is the  nature of this beast? It comes to  you on bat's wings and clawed feet,  does it not? It breathes fire, does  it not? And it lives under ground.  This is no dragon. This is Lucifer!
Whoever it is, he's dead.
This is Galen, who has just stepped into the hall, tatter bedraggled and triumphant.
Nay, brother! It is not as easy as  that. Allegiance to Christ, to be  sure, but also prayer and confession.  These are the arms by which Satan  may be put down.
You're talking about superstition,  friend. None of that has anything to  do with what I, Galen, have already  achieved.
He marches to the center of the gathering.
(to Valerian) You brought this stranger?
Ulrich's apprentice. He's a braggart,  but it doesn't matter.
People of Urland! Send a messenger  to the king. Vermithrax is dead.  Crushed by the power of the moon and  the stars! Laid low by ancient wisdom.  Dropped into the Abyss by mystical  practice.
Spoken like a pagan. Every word as  reprobate as it is false! (holding up his cross) Solum in hoc signo vinces!
Nihil plus mysterium!
He gestures boldly and a fireball crackles at the monk's  feet. The holy man scurries back. A hush falls upon the  congregation.

A procession of curious villagers winds its way into the  badlands. They gather on a promontory overlooking the dra lair. They stand there for a long time, a chill wind whip their garments, trying to understand what's happened. The monk is mightily displeased.
Praise God! Blessed is he that is  humble before the Lord!
Your god had nothing to do with it.
Indeed, Galen's act is already the stuff of legend:
We saw it with our own eyes. He flew  to the mountain top. He was a bird.  He brought forth lightning. I saw  it.

Some of the younger villagers scamper forward to the spot where the cave had its opening. With yells and whoops the beat the ground with clubs. In the crowd Simon begins to  smile, then to laugh. Soon he leads the villagers in a  tumultuous cheer. Brother Jacopus and some of his convert drop to their knees and pray.
The inhabitants of Swanscombe have decked out the town sq and are making a night of it. By torchlight they dance me to jigs and reels provided by the local fiddlers. Ale flo freely from oak casks.

Valerian is kneeling before a trunk full of women's cloth She pulls out a long simple frock, goes to a crude mirror and holds it up against her body to gauge the effect. Her father comes up behind her. He is angry and frightened.
Put that away. What if you were seen?
I'm going to be seen. I want to be  seen. Tonight the world finds out  that you never had a son.
No, you mustn't do that. It's too  soon. We've got to think about this,  we've got to make a plan.
Father: the danger is over.
He sits on the bed and puts his head in his hands.
I know. What am I going to say to my  friends who still mourn for their  lost girls.
You'll say you did what you had to.  This is a time for celebration --  and forgiveness.
He looks up at her, trying to imagine what it's going to like having a daughter.

Galen is surrounded by a crowd of wide-eyed kids and not few adults, entertaining them by pulling duck's eggs out their ears and causing coins to disappear. Presently he f the attention of his audience shift away to someone stand behind him. He turns to find a shy but determined Valeria sweetly decked out in her blue frock. A buzz goes through the crowd. Valerian blushes and wavers: she seems ready t bolt for home. But Galen takes her by the hand, and with  conspicuous politesse leads her to the dance.
It's forward, back and around sixth-century style: the yo sorcerer can't take his eyes off his partner. But she's t shy to return his gaze.
Looks like you've been up to a little  sorcery yourself.
Valerian doesn't know what to say.
Or is it witchcraft?
She still doesn't reply. It's all she can do to keep on  dancing.
What's the matter? A real woman never  stops talking.
I think it was much easier being a  boy.
They stand on the sidelines, watching the young couple st to the music.
The damnedest thing is, she was twice  the man of anyone else in the village.  Now she's twice the woman.
(grim) Would that I had been as clever as  her father.
Come now, Greil. Don't begrudge a  life spared.
I begrudge nothing. But I wonder at  what we have seen and how it was  done.
You were there.

I saw what I saw. But this jack-anapes  was barely ready to carry his master's  chamberpot. Isn't it strange that at  the very moment the beast is put  down we should have a holy man here  in the village?
You don't believe that superstitious  Christian rot, do you?
(defensive) It is said God works his wonders in  mysterious ways.

While the proud Simon dances in the background with his  daughter, a group of tipsy villagers clusters around Gale belching forth a drinking song. The young magician raises his own mug and joins in on the chorus. Abruptly the musi stops. The singing dies away. The ensuing silence is brok by the sound of galloping hooves. Presently three horseme appear at the end of town: Tyrian and his henchmen. They  guide their horses forward into the midst of the merry-ma Tyrian dismounts and looks around in his usual friendly w
A celebration! Don't stop on my  account. You -- musicians, more music!
The musicians leave their instruments in their laps. Tyri draws himself a measure of ale and raises it above his he
A toast! To the deed of the day! You  see, good news travels fast. The  King himself has already heard it.  And like yourselves, tonight he's  overcome with joy.
What would you have of us then?
Not a thing. It's this one. (he gestures toward  Galen) The King would meet our new benefactor  and offer his gratitude to the man  who succeeded where so many have  failed.
(sobering up) What sort of gratitude? A knife in  the belly? An arrow in the back?
Tyrian's smile freezes on his face. He steps in front of  Galen, towering over him.
My young friend, I'd as soon dispatch  you as I did the others, and for the  same reason. But his Majesty would  like a cozy chat, and commands  otherwise.
Don't go, Galen. Cast a spell and  turn them into toads. It should be  easy; that's what they are.
Tyrian regards her coolly, taking in her change of costum and its meaning.
Well, well: still plenty of cheek  under those skirts, it seems.
Having buried the dragon under a mountain, Galen decides  he's not worried about an appearance at court. He smiles Valerian.
Don't worry. I'll be back.

Three horses gallop through the moors and fens of central Urland. Galen is tucked up behind Tyrian. On the distant  horizon, the battlements of the King's castle glow in the slanting light of a new day.

Within the castle is a great hall with shafts of daylight poking in through narrow windows set high in the walls. I the middle of the room stands a carved oak throne. There Casiodorus Rex, King of Urland, a bearded man in his fift as spare and somber as the room in which he sits. He is  flanked by a few servants, assorted courtiers and Tyrian. Standing before them all is Galen, looking unhappy. He po a pitcher full of water into a small glazed goblet.
One of the best things about the  water here in Urland is that there's  so much of it -- look at that!
Water continues to pour into the goblet without overflowi Galen takes a sip.
Mmm. Good. But not cold enough.  Perhaps I could borrow a scarf from  his Majesty.
The King makes no sign. Galen approaches stiffly, takes a scarf and retreats.
I cover the goblet, so... remove,  so... and behold: winter in a mug!
And he's done it: he turns the goblet over and a small ch of ice hits the floor. The royal reaction is equally fros Galen is bombing, and he knows it.
All right. How many of you have ever  seen a table fly?

He mutters an incantation. In the audience, Tyrian notes  that Galen has his hand wrapped around the amulet. There a loud clatter as the heavy oak table before the throne b to jitter and buck. As the wine spills and plates go flyi the King wearily raises a hand.
Enough! That's fine.
Wait, it'll rise now.
Don't bother. Not necessary.
The table cracks in half and dumps a mess of fruit and  crockery at the onlookers' feet.
Tell me: the landslide -- it was  accomplished this same way?
Yes.
I see. And having rendered such unique  service to our kingdom, what would  you claim as a reward?
Please -- no payment. I have always  found magical practice to be its own  reward. I seek only some yet greater  challenge.
This handsome sentiment doesn't go over any better than h tricks.

Did you ever hear of King Gaiseric?  Of course not, you weren't even born.  He was my brother, a great King and  a valiant man-at-arms. When he  ascended to the throne, the dragon  was unbridled. No one knew where it  might strike next. So he brought  forth his broadsword and his spear,  assembled a company of his best  fighters and went out to do battle. (pause) He was never seen again. But his  attack provoked the most terrible  reprisals: whole villages incinerated,  entire crops burned. Death, famine,  horrible.
The King grimaces as the memories come flooding back.
(quietly) How did you arrogate to yourself the  role of savior?
I was invited.
Not by me. Did you ever consider the  consequences of failure?
What failure? What's the matter with  you people? You want the dragon back?
Then the beast is dead?
Yes, of course. Dead.
We shall see.

Two guards thrust Galen into a narrow cell and slam the b door shut. The young sorcerer waits until they're safely of sight, then takes out his amulet. He ponders it for a  doubtful moment. Suddenly a gloved hand darts in and whip it off his neck and out through the bars.
Thank you.
He makes an ironic salute and leaves. Galen sits down hea and stares at the stone walls.

Unseen by Galen, a figure clad in silk and lace skitters  down a murky dungeon hallway and peers around a corner.  Stealing a look at Galen is the Princess Elspeth, a fey b in her early twenties. After a moment, spooked by some  imagined noise, she flits away.

Dark clouds slide across a pale sun, throwing the ruined  land below into shadow. Soon fat droplets of rain are  splattering on the rocks above the dragon's lair. With ea tiny splash there is a sizzle and a puff of steam. These  rocks are hot!

Outside the barred window, a steady rain is falling. Insi Galen uses a chunk of limestone to inscribe a pentagram o the floor of his cell. He marks runic signs on the window sill and lintel. Then, positioning himself in the center the mystic symbol, he raises his hands and spreads his  fingers.
(authoritative) Cubiculum gravis aperat!
There's a long moment when nothing happens. A very long  moment. Finally, a thoroughly frustrated Galen leaps to t window and rattles the bars.
Open up, dammit! Fenestra gravis  aperat! Asser gravis aperat!  Divinitus!
Salve, magistrum iuvenilum.
Startled, Galen whirls around to find Elspeth standing ou his cell. She hands some food and blankets through the ba
I've studied Latin. Greek, too. Me  appelo Elspeth, filia regis.
Galen looks her over. He's never seen anyone so angelic.
How do you do.
Please don't think ill of us. My  father is a wonderful man, a wise  man. The lottery was his idea.
I see.
You don't understand. From the moment  it began, the dragon was tame. The  kingdom prospered.
And only a few had to be sacrificed.
Yes, that's true. Isn't it better  that a few should die that many might  live?
Depends on who does the dying.
Oh, but we all take our chances. My  father is a just man. My name is  entered on the lists, along with  every other young --
Virgin?
Maiden.
If you say so.
What do you mean?
(sighs) Nothing.
I've participated in every drawing  since I came of age.
Maybe.
It's true. You don't believe me. You  think I'm lying. Well I'm not.
I'm sorry. I heard a rumor. Families  with money, that sort of thing.
Don't listen to rumors. They're lies.  I have to go now.
Wait -- how long do I have to stay  in here?
Until we know. Not long. Goodbye.  Vale. Dormi bene.
She slips away down the corridor.
King Casiodorus and Tyrian are huddled over a table piled high with manuscripts and papers. Tyrian clears a spot an sets out a stack of lead bars.
That's enough. Let's not be greedy  here.
The King picks up Galen's amulet, and holds it over the b in his clenched fist.
Now then: I, Casiodorus Rex do hereby  command thou base metal to change  thy essence and become gold.
There is a rustle of skirts and Elspeth appears behind hi
Father?
Not now. Tyrian, remove all but one  bar. We'll try it one at a time.
Father: did you know that some  families have paid bribes to stay  out of the lottery?
The King and Tyrian glance up at her.
Nonsense. By the power of this amulet,  justly wielded by my hand in  accordance with the laws of Urland,  now lead be thou gold.
The lead remains unchanged, but the King gives out a cry drops the amulet.
I'm burned! What devilish thing is  this?
Have you ever kept my name off the  lottery list?
That'll be all, Tyrian. You may  withdraw.
Tyrian bows and exits. The King uses his sceptre to pick the amulet and chain. He conceals it in a hollowed-out bo and places the volume on a shelf among many others.
Now, my dear, what's troubling you?
Answer my question: am I not exposed  to the same risk as every other man's  daughter?
The King paces over to the window and stares out. The rai has stopped.
Well?
(finally) Your father loves you very much.
Elspeth sways in dismay.
(a wail) It's true! What have you done to  me!?
Who fills your head with such ideas?
At that moment a tremor passes through the room. King and daughter look at each other in alarm.
The same tremor shakes the bars in Galen's cell. Puzzled, rolls off his straw palette and gets to his feet. The tre dies away. Suddenly a violent shaking hits the cell, boun Galen off the walls.
Swanscombe is gripped by the same earthquake. Dodging pan barnyard animals, Valerian and her father join other  frightened villagers in the center of town.
Above the dragon's lair, boulders are shifting and grindi together. Massive chunks of stone break loose and tumble  down the incline.
The shaking has stopped. Rock dust filters down from the  ceiling. Galen picks himself up and stares: the door to h cell is off its hinges and is sagging open. He darts out.
Galen dashes along the hallway, rounds a corner and stops At the other end of the passage is Tyrian.
You little meddler! It's alive!
He draws his sword and advances. Galen warily retreats. T breaks into a run. Galen turns and sprints away.
Unruly horses, terrified by the quake, rush blindly aroun the courtyard. Hostlers try vainly to catch them. Tyrian  leans down from an upstairs window.
Close the main gate! Quick!
The men below scramble for the gates. Galen bursts out of hiding, sees the untended horses, and swings aboard as on goes past. A cry goes up from the guards.
There! Stop him!

Galen rides like mad for the exit, but he's a half-second late: the doors boom shut in his face. He wheels the hors around. The King's men are coming toward him with pikes.  Digging his heels into the horse's sides, he urges the an back across the courtyard, up the steps and right into th building!
Galen gallops into the empty chamber, knocking over the t and vaulting a table. Hot on his heels are armed soldiers He kicks the horse again and shoots under an archway.

The kitchen is already in chaos from the earthquake when  Galen charges in on his wild steed. Food, utensils and co go flying. He reins in, ducks his head, and squeezes the  horse out into a narrow hallway.
He clatters down the passageway. But here comes a conting of footmen from the opposite direction. Galen rides them  into the walls!
The horse scrabbles up the stairs, Galen tucked low again its neck. On the upper landing he comes face to face with Tyrian and more soldiers.
Get him! Stab the horse!
Galen jerks the animal around and plunges back down the  stairs.
Whinnying and blowing the horse bursts in, a wild-eyed Ga still in the saddle. He finds himself confronting the Kin and his daughter. Casiodorus grabs Elspeth and retreats into a corner.
Tyrian! Tyrian!
Tyrian sweeps in with his men. The doors slam shut.
So much for your magic! So much for  your sorcery!

Galen is trapped. Just as Tyrian reaches for the horse's  reins, the animal rears up, rolling its eyes. At that mom the floor heaves and cracks in a new series of shocks. Th men at arms go down like ten pins. Tyrian reels back, dod stone blocks loosened from the ceiling. As the shaking  continues, a weakened section of wall gives way. Galen se daylight! Without even waiting for the quake to cease, he prods the horse across the room and through the wall to  freedom.

The unnerved citizens of Swanscombe gather on the promont overlooking Galen's landslide. Every few seconds there is new shudder and more rocks pour down the long slope. Vale stands trembling with her father. Presently Brother Jacop elbows his way forward.
Listen to me, my brethren. The moment  of our fear is the moment of our  triumph. This is a sign from God.  Follow me, and our faith will send  this creature straight to hell.
Holding a cross before him, he starts up the slope. No on follows. They haven't been Christians all that long. One two near Valerian get down on their knees and pray silent Greil looks things over.
You call yourselves Christians?
He strides after the monk. But he's the only one.
The determined monk has arrived at the epicenter. His san are smoking on the hot gravel. Sweat shines on his face a neck.
The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not  want. Thou makest me to lie down in  green pastures. Thy rod and staff  they comfort me...
Greil toils up the slope a hundred yards back. He's cross himself, but he's carrying a sickle.
There is a thunderous noise. Part of the mountain is toss into the air. Up from the depths comes a huge shining win Then a neck uncoils and a head appears. It tips down towa the tiny human.
(firm) ...for Thine is the kingdom and the  power and the glory forever -- amen.
At the base of the slope the villagers scatter. Greil wav
Unclean beast, get thee down! Be  thou consumed by the fires that made  you!
The dragon's head sways back and forth, then belches out waterfall of flame. It engulfs Jacopus and sends him to a better world, if there is one.

Horse and rider race across a night landscape under brood clouds. Up ahead, the sky glows with an angry red light. the crest of a hill Galen reins in and looks down across long valley. There, miles away, is the village of Swansco Many buildings are ablaze. As he watches in horror, fires spring up in the fields and trees. Intermittently he can the silhouette of the dragon as it spreads destruction.  Finally the creature swoops up and away. Galen stares sky losing sight of it in the clouds. For a moment, silence.  Then, with a thunderous rush of air that almost blows him from the saddle, the dragon reappears and hurtles a few f over his head! It is gone in an instant.

Half the buildings in the town are on fire. Desperate  villagers dash here and there, herding children and anima to safety, trying to save their household goods. Galen wa woodenly into the confusion, leading his horse, taking in the scope of the disaster. He comes upon a line of men wh have formed a bucket brigade. He attempts to join up. As  soon as he is recognized, he is shouldered roughly aside.
Get away, you little bastard. We've  had enough help from you.

Galen staggers back, reaching for his horse. The animal s and trots off. A middle-aged woman appears in front of hi her face contorted with rage. She swings a flaming broom catches him on the back of the head. Galen reels away.
This is your doing!
Galen looks up and sees a couple of burlies moving his wa with boards in their hands.
Get him! He's back!
Before they can get too close, Galen runs down an alley a bumps smack into a glassy-eyed, haunted man. It is Greil.
Greil -- help!
May the Lord forgive you for what  you have done.
He pushes past. Galen ducks behind a smoldering building.

The roof has burned off, but at least the walls are stand Valerian is wrestling charred timbers out of the center o the room. She is covered with soot. There is a hammering the door and Galen barges in. He slams the door behind hi and puts his back against it.
It's me. Are you hurt?
Where have you been? Doesn't matter --  listen: Quick! Make it rain. That'll  put the fire out.
I can't.
Then get the animals back. They're  all running loose. There's people  been hurt. Stop their pain. You can  cure them. And we'll need food...
I can't do it.
(this stops her) What? Why not?
Galen's hand moves up to where the amulet used to hang.
I just can't.
But you're a sorcerer.
I'm no sorcerer. Whatever power I  might have had, it's gone.
It can't be!
I know: I'm an imposter. A fraud. A  fake. I'm sorry...
For a moment, Valerian is too stunned to speak. Then her  face colors.
You're sorry?! Listen to that! The  damn thing is loose, we're all on  fire and you're sorry!
Galen sinks to the floor and sits in the ashes.
You didn't have the faintest idea  what you were doing, did you? You're  a fool -- and I'm a bigger one for  bringing you here.
She snatches up a pitchfork and glowers at him.
I don't want you in this house. Get  out.
But Galen still sits there like a puppet with its strings cut, every dream of glory utterly crushed. This piteous s touches Valerian's heart. Her gaze softens. She slowly lo the pitchfork.
A knot of villagers lead Tyrian and his henchmen across t square directly to the blacksmith's shop. The King's men  dismount and pound on the door. It swings open. Valerian standing there.
Where is he?
Not here. I can't help you.
A cry goes up from the villagers. They know damn well he' in there.

Tyrian pushes Valerian aside and steps into the room. Aid by some townfolk, his men proceed to ransack the premises overturning barrels, sticking their swords through flour  sacks, poking through the tumbledown thatch. Valerian's e falls on Malkin, who has involved himself in the search.
You too?
(returning her look) Damn right.

Finding nothing, the group pushes into the metal shop, wh Simon is hammering an iron wheel rim back into shape on a enormous anvil. He lays down his tools and grimly watches the men go through, overturning benches and tables. Tyria props a leg up on the anvil and addresses himself to Simo
As the proud new father of an eligible  daughter who was some-how overlooked  all these years, it may interest you  to know that the King has called for  a new lottery.
But it's months til the solstice.
In view of what's happened, we all  know what's required.
I've never taken part in your cursed  lottery, and I'll have nothing to do  with it now.
You were very clever. But she'll  take part, like all the rest. No  exceptions.
The search party has exhausted the room's hiding places.
Nothing. If he was here, he's gone  now.
Tyrian nods and leads the way out. Simon catches up and p Tyrian aside at the door.
All right. I know what you want. How  much?
Are you offering me a bribe?
Yes.
Don't waste your time. (pause) You could never afford it.

He spins on his heel and joins his men as they ride out o town. Valerian and Simon watch them go. When the riders a out of sight, they return to the shop. With a couple of s poles, they strain to lift the anvil off its base. Finall it topples over. Valerian slides the base aside, revealin trap door. She raises it and a cramped Galen unfolds hims from the space below. On his face is a curious look of  determination.
Smith -- have you ever forged a  weapon?

Simon is going through a cabinet, tossing out hoes, rakes sickles, scythes, plow blades, and a knife or two. Galen  examines them doubtfully. Now Simon produces an armload o swords. Galen is impressed; he looks them over carefully, testing and rejecting them in turn.
These are your sharpest?
Simon plucks up one of the swords, carries it to the cent of the room. He lays a horseshoe on the anvil. He brings sword down -- whack! -- and cuts the horseshoe in half.
Even Tyrian carries one of these.
Galen hefts it dubiously.
It's sharp -- but it's not sharp  enough.
Valerian has been watching all this with growing concern.
Not sharp enough for what?
For what I'm going to do with it.
Nothing's that sharp.

Simon gnaws his lip. Reluctantly, he brings a long box fr the bottom of the cabinet. He opens it. Lying on a bed of silk is an exquisite two-handed broadsword. The flat blad gleams like a mirror. Galen reaches in and lifts it out.
The best I ever made.
Valerian is as awed as Galen.
It's beautiful.
Galen brings up a finger to test the edge. Simon grabs hi hand away.

Don't do that! (he looks at Valerian) Girl-child, when you were born I  knew I had to do something, so I set  about the task of fashioning an  extraordinary weapon: I had the skill  to make it -- (bleak pause) -- but not the nerve to use it.
She looks at him with affection. Leaning forward, she pla a kiss on his bald pate.
I'm thankful for that. (to Galen) No man should choose a senseless  death.
Galen, Valerian and Simon tramp through a glade to a moss bank. There a wide stream flows lazily under a canopy of  trees.
If it's me you're worried about,  don't. So my name has been entered,  what of it? There are hundreds of  girls. My name just won't be drawn.  I know it won't.
Galen walks out into the shallows and pushes the sword-ti into the sandy bottom, angled so that the edge splits the current.
Valerian, this isn't just for your  sake.
He walks back to shore. All three watch the sword to see  what will happen.

Big flat oak leaves are gliding along the current. Very  slowly, they go by the sword, some of them very close.  Finally, one of them floats against the leading edge of t blade and without a ripple is cleft in two. Simon gives G a significant look.
I don't care. It doesn't matter.  What you want to kill isn't flesh  and blood.
Oh, it'll bleed, all right.
How do you know? No one's so much as  even scratched it.
They look to Galen. The apprentice's face is full of doub
I'll need the amulet.

Carrying torches to light their way, families -- some wit maiden daughters -- gather from all over the country in t courtyard of the King's castle. Simon is there with Valer and so is Galen, disguised in rough farm clothes and a wi brimmed hat. Like many others, he carries a stick topped  with a bleached skull -- to all appearances, just another participant in this weird pagan ritual. A barrel decorate with flames and dragon's wings sits on a raised dais in f of the main entrance. Horsrik, the King's herald, supervi preparations for the lottery. Armed guards appear carryin sealed chest. Horsrik breaks the seal and the guards pour the contents -- hundreds of wooden tiles, each bearing th name of a potential sacrifice -- into the barrel. Trumpet blare and drums roll and the royal party strolls onstage: the King, his daughter, courtiers and Tyrian. Valerian nu Galen.
(pointing) Look at her. The Princess.
I know. We've met.
Valerian gives Galen a sharp look. Horsrik unrolls a  parchment.

(reading) People of Urland: whereas the peace  of the kingdom has been disrupted by  the mischief of an interloper; and  whereas this interloper being fled;  now therefore, his majesty the King  hereby proclaims the sum of thirty  ducats to be paid to anyone producing  the miscreant Galen Bradwardyn, fraud  enchanter, to our satisfaction.

Galen pulls his hat low over his eyes. As the moment for drawing approaches, Valerian becomes more and more uneasy She pushes forward through the crowd until she's just bel the barrel. She eyes the people around her. Some of them  seem equally worried, others -- the better dressed and be fed -- are smug and complacent. The King and his retinue serene. A chant goes up from the crowd:
Stir the tiles! Stir the tiles!
Horsrik picks up a wooden staff surmounted by a carved  dragon's head and stirs up the names. This done, a new ch goes up:
Bare the arm! Bare the arm!

At a signal, a guard comes forward and cuts the sleeve fr Horsrik's right arm. He holds it high. The crowd surges  forward. The atmosphere is full of dread and excitement.  Valerian looking pale and determined, is jostled and push to the edge of the platform.
Draw the name! Draw the name!
The moment has come. Down goes Horsrik's arm and up it co holding one little wooden square, one young woman's fate. expectant hush falls over the mob. The virgins of Urland  tremble and wait.

Now, my countrymen, hear me: behold,  for I am chosen. I shall die that  many may live. I shall lay down my  life for family and fellows. I shall  go to my grave for the love of our  King and his wise policy. And my  name is --

He looks down at the tile to read the name, but no sound  comes to his lips. He looks back at the crowd, a cold swe breaking over his face. He swallows, but still can't brin himself to speak. At his feet, Valerian is holding her br A new chant goes up.
The name! The name!
By now Horsrik is trembling. He stares down at the tile, mouth set in a grim line. The King is getting annoyed. He gestures and the crowd falls silent.
Read the name.
(mastering himself) The name is: Princess Elspeth Ulfilas,  filia regis.

There is a moment of profound shock. Then a low murmur of wonder moves through the crowd. Galen looks at Valerian; sags with relief. The King turns to his daughter. She sho nothing. He rises from his chair, comes forward and snatc the tile from Horsrik.
That's not the name. It's been  misread.
Valerian will not stand for such hypocrisy.
There's no mistake! The name's been  chosen -- let it stand!
No, the good Horsrik has misspoke  himself. (he looks at the tile) In fairness to this individual, whose  name I can't make out, we'll destroy  this tile.
He quickly tosses the wood chip into a brazier at his elb Led by Valerian, the crowd cries out in protest.
No! What better name than your own  kin? At last we see justice done!
Silence! We will have a new choosing.  I will draw the name myself.
He reaches into the barrel and extracts another tile. He  looks at it and his eyes widen. Betrayed, he swivels to f his daughter. The din of the crowd reaches a crescendo.
Let it stand! Let it stand!
Elspeth takes the tile from her father's nerveless finger looks at it with satisfaction and holds it aloft.
The name is as you heard it and as  Horsrik read it: Elspeth.
The King moils through the tiles, finding his daughter's  name again and again.
The lottery is invalid. Another and  another. What treachery is this?
Valerian, chanting with the rest, falls silent. She looks Elspeth with sudden interest and respect, then awe.

Hear me, good people! It is true,  that my name appears on many of the  lots. This does not falsify the  drawing, it certifies it! I have  learned that my name has been kept  from jeopardy in all the drawings in  the past. So I have put my name among  the rest many times -- once for each  risk that, over the years, you took  and I did not.

The crowd is dumbfounded. Gradually voices erupt in a  cacophony of shouts, whistles and excited conversation. G sees his chance: there's an unguarded door near the stabl He drifts toward it and slips inside.

Galen pokes his head in: the room is empty. He scurries o to a chest, flings it open and starts rummaging. Finding  nothing he moves on to a cabinet. He breaks the lock and  pries it open. Again, nothing.

Galen can hear the voices in the courtyard as he rushes d a hall. Suddenly he stops short. There in front of him is guard leaning out a window to watch the proceedings. Gale hovers on the verge of panic as the guard abruptly moves. But the man is only headed for another window and a bette view. Galen manages to fall into step an arm's length beh him and slip by without a sound.

Galen enters the library, his enormous shadow dancing cra on the torchlit walls. Hurrying through, his attention is drawn to some open books on a table. Closer inspection re magical writings and symbols. Galen paws over everything, suddenly aware that he must be close to the amulet. But w is it?
As the crowd disperses Valerian watches Elspeth walk back the castle, lofty and composed. She looks for Galen and  discovers he has gone.

By now, the room is in total disarray. Galen has opened a the chests and trunks and knocked half the books from the shelves. No amulet. He's feverishly working on a locked d when a voice interrupts him.
Don't go to all that trouble.

Galen whirls around to find the King standing in the door The monarch looks shattered. Galen edges toward the split the wall and finds that it has been shored up with timber At that moment Tyrian comes through the door, sizes up th situation and draws his sword.
I'm unarmed. If you want a fight, at  least give me a weapon.
(pushing by the King) I think not!
Stop! Don't harm him. (to Galen) And you -- don't run away... please...
The King's voice is cracking. Galen and Tyrian are equall taken aback. The King searches through the books remainin on the library shelves.

(shaky) I've always had the greatest  admiration for the black arts. You  chaps with your mysterious spells...  I didn't think it would be necessary,  you see. Vermithrax is an old dragon.  And that, I thought, was the beauty  of my plan -- buying time. We'd wait  her out. I'd live to see the end of  her. (firm) That's still going to happen.
The King finds the book and takes the amulet out. With  trembling hands, he passes it to Galen.
Sire!
He shall have it. (pleading) It's my daughter. Save her, I beg  you.

The people of Swanscombe are clearing up the rubble and  beginning repairs on their dwellings. Standing in their m lecturing every passerby, is Greil. He holds up the charr remains of Brother Jacopus' wooden cross.
Holy of holies -- he did not die in  vain. Can you hear me, brothers?
Some workmen go by lugging new thatch. Malkin is with the
(gently) We hear you, Greil.
Well and good, but I'm Greil no  longer. Call me Gregorius, after the  Bishop of Rome.
Malkin and the others stop to listen.
I saw him die. Like Our Lord Jesus  on the cross he was, scourged by  evil. But he showed no fear. Such is  the power of the Holy Ghost.
Galen lurks in the shadows of Simon's metal shop looking on the square where Greil is holding forth.
Of what avail is magic? The old gods  died with our daughters. From whence  comest my help? My help comest from  the Lord!
Galen quietly shuts and bars the door. He moves deeper in the gloomy workroom where Simon is pumping a bellows to h up the forge. Galen looks at the coals.
Good and hot.
Don't bother. That's not the kind of  fire we need.
Valerian is staring at the sword, sitting on the anvil in its silk wrapping. Galen uncovers it, holds it high, and  puts his hand on the amulet.
Nunc, per Potestatem Hermeticum --  ex flammis, ferrum sangrinarium!

The sword starts to hum and to heat up. From the hilt out the blade glows brighter and brighter: red, orange, white It lights up the room, throwing long shadows into the cor Galen lays the white hot steel on the anvil. Simon takes his hammer and begins the reforging. Valerian sees their  resolve. After watching for several moments she slips out the side door, looking sad.

Clouds scud low over the lifeless region. The dragon's la now has a newer, bigger entrance. Vapors drift upward fro it. Down the slope a lonely figure works its way from roc to rock: it's Valerian with a wicker basket on her arm,  searching for dragon scales. The basket is already more t half full when she finds herself ominously near the mouth the cavern. She's about to turn back when she spies a  particularly large and beautiful scale just a few yards  further on. As she reaches for it, there is a sudden hiss She jerks her hand back and freezes. There in the shadows a baby dragon, a basilisk, all coppery bronze with stubby winglets. As she backs away, she sees two more come up to join the first. They watch her retreat through wicked lit green eyes.

On the mossy bank Galen and Simon unwrap the reforged swo Now the blade carries a faint blue halation. Galen walks the middle of the current and once again stabs the tip do into the sand. Then he rejoins Simon onshore to await res This time, as the oak leaves approach the sharp edge, the gently but definitely veer sideways to avoid contact. Suc is the power of the sword that even after many leaves, no single one has come close enough to be sliced. Simon is a and even Galen seems satisfied. They clasp hands.
An edge like no other on this earth.
Well done, Simon. Thank you.
Simon hands him a bundle of fighting equipment.
(grave) I'll say goodbye to Valerian for  you. I'm sorry she's not here, but  you know how she is.
I understand.
They look at each other for what could be the last time.
Fare thee well.

The old man departs. Galen unfolds the bundle and brings its contents: mail hauberk with coif, studded leather glo padded jerkin, a scabbard and a small wooden shield. He l them out on the stream bank, then strips off his tunic an kneels down to splash some water in his face. As the cups the water between his hands, an image comes alive and shi on the surface: Valerian, stripping off her own clothes,  shyly turning toward him, solemn and romantic.
Galen.
It's as if the vision is speaking to him, but it's not. H spins around and sees her standing there, fully clothed, possessed of a brisk and businesslike air.
Here.
She throws down a shield. It's remarkable in its construc overlapping layers of iridescent dragon scales have been  ingeniously fastened to a leather-clad frame.

It's a shield. I made it. Might keep  the fire off you. Might not. You  know, you're an idiot. You're going  to die tonight. You'll be ripped  limb from limb. This is the last  time I'll ever speak to you.
Galen turns the shield over and over, marveling at it. He fixes her with a piercing look.
Thank you.
(rushing) Another thing. That thing isn't alone  up there. There's little ones. Young,  I think. I don't know how many.
She shudders. Galen's eyes are still fastened on her. She fighting to retain her hard manner, but the agitation and dread are plain.
Hatchlings. They'll have to be killed  too. Anything else?
Valerian wants to be bold, but on this final point, can't muster the courage.
(tiny voice) You're in love, aren't you?
(slowly nodding) Yes.
That's all right. I understand. She's  very beautiful, very brave.
Who is? What do you mean?

Your Princess. But I don't care. It  doesn't change the way I feel. (firm) Listen to me, Galen Bradwardyn,  sorcerer's apprentice; you're going  to be dead, the dragon will be worse  than ever, there will be more  lotteries, and I'm not a boy any  more.
And you'll be eligible because --
Because I'm still a virgin, and I  want you to do something about it.
Galen takes her in his arms; she is trembling. He tilts h face up toward his and kisses her.
I am in love. But not with the  Princess.

Their image is reflected in the waters. Through the rippl she is visible pulling briefly away to remove her clothes From afar, they are two tiny figures under the overarchin oaks and willows. They embrace and sink down into the dee grass beside the water. The leaves continue their unhurri course downstream.

A cold wind whistles through the rocks near the dragon's  lair. By the light of a flickering torch two workmen fini driving a heavy post into the ground. As they affix a pai of iron manacles they see the torches of a procession com up the slope. They hurry down to meet it. Horsrik is in t lead, followed by soldiers and royal attendants. Elspeth  rides in the tumbril behind a blindfolded horse. Bringing the rear is Tyrian. At last the cart can go no further.  Elspeth alights and leads the rest of the troop to the po As the soldiers put the irons around her wrists, Horsrik  unrolls a parchment, turns his back on the wind and begin to read:
Now be it known throughout the  kingdom, that the Princess, having  been chosen by a deed of fortune and  destiny --

Horsrik blinks. There's a black stain growing in the midd of the parchment; all at once it bursts into flames. He c out and flings the document away. There follows a flash o light and a puff of smoke and Galen is standing there, as he had materialized out of thin air. Horsrik and his star men backpedal down the slope.
No fire, I beg you.
Galen raises his hands in a menacing gesture.
Be gone!
That's enough for Horsrik and company: he and the soldier depart.
(over his shoulder) I declare these proceedings duly  ordained...
Only one man remains behind the challenge the young sorce Tyrian. He draws his sword.
I knew I'd find you here. Well, I'm  not as sentimental as some. The  kingdom, every one of us, need this  sacrifice. If you intend to interfere,  you'll have to kill me.
I've got plenty of reasons to kill  you that have nothing to do with  this sacrifice.
Galen draws his own sword. As it emerges into the night a it seems imbued with a blue phosphorescence.
Most impressive. Can you use it?
Elspeth twists around in her chains.
Let it be! Please! Tyrian is right --  it's our only hope!

Galen starts to reply, but as soon as his attention waver Tyrian is lunging toward him, sword point directed at his neck. Galen barely manages to parry the thrust before Tyr is at him again, blade swinging toward his knees. Galen d the tip of his sword to catch the blow. When the two stee edges connect, sparks fly. In a series of thrusts and cou thrusts, each accompanied by a shower of sparks, Tyrian b Galen up the mountain.
Tyrian -- both of you -- run! Flee!  It's coming!
Sure enough, at that moment the earth gives out a low moa and undulates in a sickening movement. Vapors begin risin from the lair.
In a trice! This is no swords-man.

He might be right, for Galen turns and bolts across the s When he reaches the post with Tyrian two steps behind, he whirls and brings his blade down on Princess Elspeth's ch The chains part in an explosion of sparks.
Run! Get out of here!
The Princess darts from the piling as Tyrian swoops down continue the attack. Galen dodges and the stake catches  Tyrian's blow. The earth shakes again. Galen glances at t Princess.
