No! Stop! What are you doing?

Elspeth is not running away down the mountain. Instead sh is walking, slowly and deliberately, right into the smoki cave. Swoosh! Tyrian's sword comes down again. The dismay sorcerer ducks back and Tyrian's blade again bites deep i the wood.
You've failed, my friend, and I thank  the gods for it. Come out from behind  that post.

It's now or never. Elspeth is no longer in sight. Galen g his teeth, grasps the sword with two hands and swings it hard as he can in a wide arc. The blade never even slows  down as it sails right through the post, lopping it clean off. The glowing sword flashes above Galen's head and eag buries itself in Tyrian's chest. The King's man is as sta by the amputated piling as he is by his own death. His ey roll up in his head, his knees buckle and he topples back the blade sliding free.
Smoke swirls at the mouth of the cave as Galen enters, ho his sword before him, lighting his way with its faint blu glow.
Elspeth!

The floor of the cave as it winds down into the mountain paved first with rock, then with dragon scales, then with bones. With each footfall, clusters of mysterious insects scuttle away. Galen pauses to mop his brow; it's getting  hot. A sound echoes up from the depths, a grinding sound  like the gnashing of teeth, followed by hissing and squea Galen grips his sword tighter and pushes on. Suddenly he  stoops and picks up an embroidered slipper: Elspeth's. Th grinding sounds are louder. He hurries forward and rounds corner. He stops and gags.

Two disgusting little reptiles -- like scaly raccoons -- perched on the corpse of Princess Elspeth Ulfilas, feedin contentiously on choice bits of the royal flesh. Galen gr he lashes out and his sword beheads one of the tiny monst The other one buzzes its half-formed winglets and hisses hot stream of air. Galen brings down the sword and slices in half. Eyes riveted on Elspeth's remains, he edges arou the carnage and backs away. Hissss! -- there's a third on lurking in the shadows, munching on something; it might b hand. Galen shrieks and jumps away. The little creature c at him and clamps its jaws on his leg. Galen stabs at it  repeatedly. Finally it lets go, and flails and flops acro the bloody floor, ululating its death agony. As the creat last mewlings echo down through the cavern, the ground  quivers. Bits of stone fall from the ceiling.

Galen works his way down a narrow passage whose walls are alive with insects and beads of sulphurous water. As befo he holds the sword in front of him; he marvels at its  increasing brightness. The heat is increasing too; sweat  mats his hair and runs down his face. A few yards further the sword starts pulsating. Now the walls take on a flick rosy sheen and the passage widens into an underground vis of staggering immensity: an underground lake, its surface bubbling and torn with sheets of flame. Arching over it i vault of stone, penetrated here and there by natural chim The dimensions of this internal world are unknown -- the  fiery lake disappears into half a dozen side chambers. Th one clear path is accessible only by a series of flat sto leading across the hot liquid. Galen grips his sword and  resolutely hops from rock to rock.

He's halfway across when the earth rumbles and the steppi stones teeter beneath his feet. A fiery wave washes over legs, leaving his boots smoking. Another tremor knocks Ga to his knees. As he scrabbles to pick up his sword and sh the great head of Vermithrax rises up out of the depths o its long neck. It gazes at him through huge pale eyes und armored lids. A tongue flicks out and runs around its lip mouth. The head sways from side to side. The mouth hinges open, the nostril-like igniters come on and touch off the jet of gas squeezed up out of its innards. A roaring tube flame engulfs Galen. He crouches behind his dragon scale  shield which deflects the fire just enough to save his li The dragon pauses to take a breath. Galen springs to his  feet, and bounds back the way he came, his skin and cloth singed. Flames lick at his back as the dragon lets fly wi a second burst.

Coughing and weeping, Galen staggers up through the tunne nearly tripping over the body of one of the baby dragons. few seconds later, Vermithrax follows, squirming and claw its way upward. When it reaches its dead offspring it sur the scene with expressionless eyes. Bringing its head low it sniffs and nudges at the lifeless little ones.

At that moment Galen leaps out from behind a niche in the tunnel wall and lunges forward. Striking sparks, the poin of his sword slides across the dragon's plated cheek and  stabs deep between the scales of its heavy neck. There is unearthly shriek and the creature flicks its head back an upward. Galen goes sprawling and finds himself holding ha a sword. The rest is buried in the beast's neck, and  Vermithrax doesn't like it. It flings its head this way a that, knocking rocks loose from the ceiling. Its movement cause the ground to quake. As boulders tumble around him, Galen drops to the floor under his shield. Dragon flame  reaches through the cascading debris and washes over him.

Valerian roams the rock-strewn slope not far from the dra lair. Presently she comes upon a once-familiar object -- fire shield. Half the scales are gone, the rest are charr and curling. Grimly, she moves on. A few paces away she p up the blunted sword. She scans the rocks and finally see what she's looking for.
He's lying face down behind a boulder, his clothes charre patches of skin scorched. He looks dead. Valerian rolls h onto his back. She gasps: the eyes are open, regarding he
Still alive.
Simon is standing by the anvil with the broken sword in h hand, lost in thought.
In the adjoining house Valerian tends Galen's wounds. He' propped up on a palette enduring the application of poult
You know what we have to do. (he looks at her with  dull eyes) We have to leave Urland.
He winces in pain.

Not because of what happened. I  brought you here -- it didn't work --  now I'm taking you away. Do you  understand? (Galen does not react) You said you loved me. Is it true?  If it is, it's the only good we've  done. Let's not lose that too. (pause) Galen?
He seems miles away. She turns aside, on the verge of tea Simon is standing there, still holding the sword hilt.

She's right. What kind of a life  could you have here? It's too late  for me, but you're young enough. (he shows them the  sword) You know what I think? Magic is dying  out, fading from the world. But that  makes me happy. That means the dragon  will be dying too.
Galen looks at him; he has heard everything. He sits up a fondly regards Valerian.

Valerian packs her belongings into a rucksack. The last i in is her blue frock, carefully rolled. Beside her, Galen dons clean traveling clothes. He stiffly crosses the room and drags his pack out of the corner. He sorts through th effects, and amidst the clothing and supplies discovers t leather pouch containing Ulrich's remains. He contemplate it.
What's that?
Nothing. I was just thinking -- poor  Hodge.
He tucks the pouch away, throws some clothes on top and t the satchel shut.
Beside the quiet stream Simon bids farewell to the young  couple, embracing each in turn. They slosh across the sha water and follow a path into the woods.

Greil is standing outside the half-burned grange hall,  summoning the Christian faithful. He proclaims the call t worship by hammering on a small bell. One by one the town arrive. Among them is Simon, looking bereft.
Valerian and Galen trudge along side by side.
How's your leg?
Hurts. That thing was small, but its  teeth were sharp.
At least you killed it. You got all  the young.
This is small consolation, and Galen sighs.
But the big one's alive. Somewhere  down in that burning lake.
